Caption: Fig. 1. Monoscopic and low-resolution approximations of hologram visualizations of 3D scatterplots using immersive tangible augmented reality with the HoloLens. Actual perception through the HoloLens provides stereoscopic images and higher resolution.
Fig. 2. Classification of the three visualization environments used in our study for perception, interaction, and proximity.
Table 1. Environment configurations as used in the study.
Fig. 3. Study setup (top row) and approximate user perspectives (bottom row) in each environment.

Fig. 4. Example stimuli for two tasks. (a) distance: participants had to estimate which pair of colored points (red or yellow) had the smaller spatial distance. (b) selection: participants had to select the red points.

Fig. 6. Example for cuttingplane task where participants had to intersect sian distribution with standard deviation of 0.5 units. Accuracy was the three red clusters with the cutting plane. Yellow points served as calculated as sum of the distance of each cluster’s geometric center to handles for rotating the cutting plane. the cutting plane placed by the participants.

Fig. 5. Example for cluster task: (a) perspective projection showing all as a semi-transparent plane (Fig. 6) controlled by mouse interaction. 5 clusters. (b-d) seen from different sides where some clusters overlap. After trying different interactions we decided on the following 3-DOF Participants had to report the lowest number of clusters observed. approach: dragging the mouse on the plane surface translates the plane

Fig. 7. Results for time (seconds), error, and subjective reported preci- sion (5-point Likert scale) by task. Confidence intervals indicate 95% confidence for mean values. Dashed lines indicate significances for p < .05. Highlighted bars indicate significant best results.
Fig. 8. Subjective ratings and perceived performances as indicated by the participants (0-9 Likert scale). Error bars: 95% CIs.
